title: 115_hr3179
content: The Act titled "Transparency and Accountability for Business Standards Act" requires cost-benefit analysis for certain prudential regulations. The Act mandates that Federal banking agencies must provide a detailed rationale and cost-benefit analysis when adopting prudential regulations stricter than international standards. This includes assessing impacts on credit availability, market liquidity, institution competitiveness, employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. The Act requires Federal banking agencies to justify adopting stricter prudential regulations compared to international standards. This includes evaluating impacts on credit availability, market liquidity, institution competitiveness, employment, economic growth, and monetary policy execution. Additionally, agencies must not implement regulations that would supersede existing ones without public notice and comment on repealing or amending the superseded regulations. The Act mandates Federal banking agencies to justify stricter prudential regulations compared to international standards. Agencies must evaluate impacts on various aspects like credit availability, market liquidity, and economic growth. They are also required to issue reports to Congress within 180 days of enacting rules that supersede existing regulations, detailing the rationale for not repealing or amending them. Definitions for terms like "appropriate Federal banking agency" and "banking organization" are provided in the section. The Act defines terms like "corresponding international prudential standard" and "prudential regulation" related to capital, leverage, and liquidity requirements for banking organizations. The Act defines terms related to prudential regulation based on international standards set by institutions like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board. The term "superseded prudential regulation" refers to a regulation that addresses similar risks or achieves similar goals as an international standard set by entities like the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and the Financial Stability Board.
